programme.title: Saturday Night Live
programme.desc: Live from New York, celebrity hosts join an ensemble cast to perform comedy on Saturday nights. Capturing the pop-culture zeitgeist, sketches and segments include satirical news and digital shorts and often go viral the very next day. From Executive Producer Lorne Michaels, SNL is a lauded American late-night institution and continues to earn critical praise and dozens of award nominations season-to-season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game Hollywood Squares Hour
programme.desc: Game show that combines "Match Game" and "Hollywood Squares.".(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.desc: Skoon is an all-natural, non-clumping, lightweight, eco-friendly cat litter solution to cat waste. Skoon cat litter is made from highly absorbent Diatom pebbles, which absorbs urine while trapping and eliminating odor.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Match Game PM

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Match Game Hollywood Squares Hour
programme.desc: Game show that combines "Match Game" and "Hollywood Squares.".(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: The Price Is Right
programme.desc: "Come on down!" Contestants guess retail values for prizes on TV's longest-running game show. Bob Barker racked up over a dozen hosting Emmys since CBS first aired the daytime staple in 1972. When Barker retired in 2007, Drew Carey stepped in to ably fill his shoes.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: The Price Is Right
programme.desc: "Come on down!" Contestants guess retail values for prizes on TV's longest-running game show. Bob Barker racked up over a dozen hosting Emmys since CBS first aired the daytime staple in 1972. When Barker retired in 2007, Drew Carey stepped in to ably fill his shoes.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. programme.desc: Contestants are partnered with celebrities in this charades-style game in which 'their bodies do the talking,' as host Tom Kennedy puts it.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: No More Cat Odor!
programme.desc: Skoon is an all-natural, non-clumping, lightweight, eco-friendly cat litter solution to cat waste. Skoon cat litter is made from highly absorbent Diatom pebbles, which absorbs urine while trapping and eliminating odor.(n)

programme.title: Paid Programming
programme.desc: Home Shopping Network, a leading interactive multichannel retailer which offers a curated assortment of exclusive products combined with top brand names, offers innovative, differentiated retail experiences on television.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Body Language
programme.desc: Contestants are partnered with celebrities in this charades-style game in which 'their bodies do the talking,' as host Tom Kennedy puts it.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game Hollywood Squares Hour
programme.desc: Game show that combines "Match Game" and "Hollywood Squares.".(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: The Price Is Right
programme.desc: "Come on down!" Contestants guess retail values for prizes on TV's longest-running game show. Bob Barker racked up over a dozen hosting Emmys since CBS first aired the daytime staple in 1972. When Barker retired in 2007, Drew Carey stepped in to ably fill his shoes.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Grow Hair Fast!
programme.desc: Discover the science behind rapid hair growth with ScalpMED.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Body Language
programme.desc: Contestants are partnered with celebrities in this charades-style game in which 'their bodies do the talking,' as host Tom Kennedy puts it.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game Hollywood Squares Hour
programme.desc: Game show that combines "Match Game" and "Hollywood Squares.".(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX.(n)

programme.title: Body Language
programme.desc: Contestants are partnered with celebrities in this charades-style game in which 'their bodies do the talking,' as host Tom Kennedy puts it.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game Hollywood Squares Hour
programme.desc: Game show that combines "Match Game" and "Hollywood Squares.".(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled 'Password Plus' and 'Super Password.'.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a 'cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn 'spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, 'no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman ('I've Got a Secret,' 'To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, 'Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: The Price Is Right
programme.desc: "Come on down!" Contestants guess retail values for prizes on TV's longest-running game show. Bob Barker racked up over a dozen hosting Emmys since CBS first aired the daytime staple in 1972. When Barker retired in 2007, Drew Carey stepped in to ably fill his shoes.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: An artfully simple Goodson-Todman mainstay in which three players claimed to be the same person. Four celebrity panelists questioned them before voting on who was telling the truth, with incorrect guesses netting prize money for the contestants. The moment of truth always came with the familiar words, 'Will the real [name of person] please stand up?' The show was revived in syndication in 1980, hosted by Robin Ward; in 1990, with Gordon Elliott, then Lynn Swann; and in 2000, with John O'Hurley.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: 'Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to 'fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy 'Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as 'Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days
programme.desc: Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson light up the screen in this effervescent romantic comedy. She plays a journalist writing an article on how to drive a man away; he is a slick ad executive who must make a woman fall in love with him in 10 days if he's to land a big account promoting diamonds. A breezy script and the charm of the leads make this a great date movie. Bebe Neuwirth, Robert Klein. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: Erin Brockovich
programme.desc: Julia Roberts' spirited performance sparks this riveting fact-based drama. She plays a low-level office worker who pushes her boss (Albert Finney) into representing a California town, where the drinking water has been contaminated by a utility company. Steven Soderbergh directed. Marg Helgenberger, Aaron Eckhart. (repeat).(n)

programme.desc: Luka's return does little to relieve Abby, whose old habits distance her from friends and family; Gates readjusts to parenthood as Sarah settles back into life in Chicago. programme.title: ER
programme.desc: In the series' 300th episode, the Kovacs prepare to travel to Croatia, but not before Luka confronts Abby about the recent distance in their relationship. Elsewhere, the husband (Peter Fonda) of a dying patient learns a haunting family secret; and the ER staff takes time out to remember patients they have lost through the years. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Still stinging from Wexler's promotion to chief, Pratt decides to leave County for a hospital that will appreciate his talents. Meanwhile, a familiar face returns to the ER and confronts a dreaded eventuality; and Neela, distracted by her cousin's unexpected visit, still manages to impress her colleagues with her abilities as a doctor. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: In the series pilot, a 29-year-old kindergarten teacher (Robin Tunney) suffers from mysterious seizures that no one on Dr. Greg House's diagnostic-medicine team can explain. Hugh Laurie, Linda Edelstein, Robert Sean Leonard. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 16-year-old boy has night terrors after getting hit on the head by a lacrosse ball, and House (Hugh Laurie) immediately suspects he's a victim of sexual abuse. Later, he changes the diagnosis to MS, and that night the youth disappears from his hospital bed. In the clinic, House treats a baby whose mother has an aversion to inoculation, and a man with an infected knee who's almost as obnoxious as House is. Dan: Scott Mechlowicz. Andy: Robin Thomas. Paula: Wendy Gazelle. Funsten: Alex Skuby. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 22-year-old man who had just called out sick from work loses consciousness after having sex with his fiancée. So he really is sick, but with what? Meanwhile, House tries out his gruff and sarcastic bedside manner on all the clinic patients at once. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: House sees two infants in the neonatal ICU and determines immediately that an infection is spreading through the hospital. He's right, of course, but what caused it? House's approach is Solomonic, in a way. Meanwhile, one of House's clinic patients is a young woman who has what he calls a "parasite." Karen: Ever Carradine. Ethan: Sam Trammell. Kim: Alexandra Chun. Jill: Hedy Burress. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: At Christmastime, a nun (Elizabeth Mitchell) arrives at the clinic with symptoms resembling stigmata, and House's initital treatment (for an allergic reaction) nearly kills her. Subsequent efforts don't work either, and lead to much soul-searching. Meanwhile, House has a highly unusual remedy for a man with an inflamed bowel. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 38-year-old mentally ill woman (Stacy Edwards) has a pulmonary embolism, something a 38-year-old shouldn't have. This intrigues House, so much that he actually wants to meet her (not just treat her condition). Knowing the woman's reality all too well is her teen, who supports her much more than she supports him. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 31-year-old woman (Myndy Crist) sleeps 18 hours a day, and when she's awake she's irritable. It isn't depression, but it will be fatal if House doesn't figure out what it is. Ed: Dominic Purcell. Samantha: Clementine Ford. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The team searches for a former IRA bomb-maker who was smuggled into the city, and are joined by Special Agent Hannah Khoury, Pride's replacement during his medical leave. Also, Pride considers a new position with the agency. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: NCIS investigates the murder of a Navy intelligence officer killed during a conference for foreign diplomats, and the key witness cozies up to Sebastian. Also, Pride has some trouble adjusting to his new position at the agency. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Kovac---who's returned to Chicago looking for hospice-care work---is significantly impacted by an upbeat terminal-cancer patient (Hal Holbrook). Meanwhile, Abby treats a beaten Korean teen; and Brenner (David Lyons) continues to rattle the ER staffers. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: Charmed
programme.desc: Popular Aaron Spelling-produced fantasy about three sexy sisters who happen to be witches living in the eerie San Francisco house where they grew up. Since each had different powers, they worked in tandem to fight evil and protect the innocent. Despite Shannen Doherty's much-publicized departure in 2000, the show continued to thrive, with Rose McGowan joining the cast as a long-lost sister.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Something poisoned a high-school student who became ill during a calculus exam, and House and his team must figure out what it was, while battling the young man's mother, who doesn't trust any of them. In the clinic, meanwhile, House admits an older woman (Shirley Knight) for tests because of a personality change: She's suddenly very interested in sex. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A jazz musician (Harry Lennix), who's already paralyzed from the waist down, collapses at a recording session (which features a cameo by Brandy). His L.A. doctor (David Conrad) is treating him for ALS, and he signs a "do not resuscitate" order. But that's not about to stop House. Meanwhile, that doctor offers Foreman a job. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A homeless Jane Doe (Leslie Hope) collapses while confronting police at an all-night rave, then has a seizure in the hospital. She turns out to be a talented cartoonist, who's diabetic and has a twitch. Wilson suspects ovarian cancer, and Foreman thinks she's faking. House, of course, has another view. He also has another audience: two medical students (Smith Cho, Ogy Durham), who are learning to take case histories. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 16-year-old boy starts bleeding just before the car crash that lands him in the hospital, and the symptoms add up to nothing but a likely death. Meanwhile, Cuddy suggests an unorthodox approach to get House off his painkillers. He takes her up on it and what follows isn't likely to be pleasant for anybody. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A major-league pitcher with a history of drug abuse (Scott Foley) develops brittle bones. Steroids could be the cause, but he insists he's clean, and tests back him up. He doesn't appear to have cancer, either. And in the clinic, House treats, if that's the word for it, five patients in three minutes. Meanwhile, Foreman is seeing an attractive drug rep, and House and Cameron share a social evening: They attend a monster-truck rally. Lola: Meredith Monroe. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 12-year-old who says he's cursed collapses after developing pneumonia-like symptoms and a rash. He had been hanging out in a dusty attic and had scraped his arm. And none of the doctors are pleased to be around the sick boy's very rich and very demanding father (Nestor Carbonell). Meanwhile, Chase's father (Patrick Bauchau), an eminent rheumatologist, arrives from Australia, but Chase is not at all happy to see him. Sarah: Tracy Middendorf. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: While House treats a 32-year-old cosmetics CEO whose leg pain turns much more serious, the hospital welcomes its new board chairman (Chi McBride). He's donated $100 million to the Princeton-Plainsboro, and now wants to run it. Not surprisingly, he isn't happy with House or his department. Carly Forlano: Sarah Clarke. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans

programme.desc: The NCIS team places Mateo Diaz, a high-school gang member-turned-informant, in protective custody while they investigate the murder of his junior reserve officers' training corps instructor. Also, Pride needs his brother Jimmy Boyd's help to gain Mateo's trust. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: NCIS: New Orleans
programme.desc: The NCIS team investigates the murder of a Navy contractor who, unbeknownst to anyone, lived two lives for decades, with two wives, families and careers. (repeat).(n)

programme.desc: While on a sunrise jog, Pride is grabbed by two masked men who order him to complete a series of tasks in order to save Wade and his father, Cassius Pride, who are being held captive. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Vogler (Chi McBride) is forcing House to fire one member of his team. Which one? He lets them fight it out as they struggle to save an obese 10-year-old who had a heart attack. Meanwhile, a woman with a huge belly won't hear of it when House tells her she's pregnant. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: Vogler offers House a way out of his personnel problem. Meanwhile, a senator (Joe Morton) with presidential ambitions doesn't believe it when House tells him he has AIDS. And a clinic patient (Mindy Crider) doesn't believe it when House tells her she had a miscarriage. She says that she hasn't had sex in a year. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: It's payback time for Vogler (Chi McBride) after House's speech, leading to boardroom sessions that would make Donald Trump blanch. But House is focused on his patients: a pregnant 39-year-old who has trouble swallowing; and a low-weight baby whose parents have been feeding her a vegan diet. According to social-services authorities that constitutes child abuse. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: During a meningitis outbreak that fills the hospital, a 12-year-old diver exhibits many of the disease's symptoms, and some other ones, too. Meanwhile, with Vogler out of the picture, House offers Cameron her job back. (repeat).(n)

programme.desc: Cameron returns on one condition---that House goes on a date with her. programme.title: House

programme.desc: House battles to save the life of a volatile death-row inmate (LL Cool J) who collapses in an exercise yard after hearing the "voices" of the four people he murdered. programme.title: House
programme.desc: A child cancer patient (Sasha Pieterse) hallucinates for no apparent reason, and bravely undergoes numerous procedures to determine the cause---too bravely, House suspects. programme.desc: A young handyman (Ignacio Serricchio) working for Cuddy falls from her roof, and his condition worsens in the hospital. Meanwhile, a black clinic patient complains of racism when Foreman gives him a blood-pressure medication targeted to blacks. (repeat).(n)

programme.title: House

programme.desc: A chief warrant officer who specialized in counterintelligence is murdered. The investigation reveals the victim's wife has been kidnapped and is being held for ransom. Meanwhile, senior FBI agent Fornell travels to the Big Easy to assist with the case. (repeat).(n)

programme.desc: The classic Gloria Monty soap charting the trials of Port Charles' medical center.
